questions.text: A surgeon attended a wedding party and had a few drinks. After the marriage party he performed a surgery. His colleagues noticed that his hands were visibly shaking while he was operating, couldn’t maintain balance while standing and he was slurring while speaking. During surgery, a major blood vessel was ruptured leading to death. Which of these would be applicable for the surgeon?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Criminal Negligence Criminal negligence is when a person does an act which is in regard to the obvious risk to the safety of human life. In this case, the surgeon was well aware of his drunk condition even before starting the surgery and was visibly affected due to this . Neglecting the obvious after effects of drinking and carrying on with the surgery which led to the blood vessel rupture and eventually, death makes the surgeon directly responsible for the patient’s death. Criminal Negligence is statutorily embodied in section 304A of Indian Penal Code (IPC) – Causing Death by negligence: “Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide , shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years. Or with fine, or with both”.

Highyeild:

Any conduct of the doctor can be booked under the following section 336, 337, 338, 304 A IPC. In Civil Negligence, the patient directly approaches the court, demanding the compensation whereas in criminal negligence, the patient approaches police & a case is filed by the police. IPC NOTE S.336 Any rash or negligent act, threatening/ endangering the life/ safety of patient Eg: Doctor conducts delivery under the influence of Alcohol S.337 Any rash / negligent act causing hurt to the patient, punishment – upto 6 months (or) 500 (or) both. S.338 IPC Any rash / negligent act causing grievous injury to patient. Punishable upto 2 yrs or 1000 or both. Eg: Operating on the wrong patient (or) the wrong eye. S.304 A IPC Any rash / negligent act causing death of patient. Punishment – imprisonment upto 2 years or fine or both.

questions.text: A 40 yr old male with alopecia came to the hospital. His wife complains of some behavioral abnormalities in him. Physical examination revealed loss of eyebrows and eyelashes on the lateral part. Doctor notices some abnormal findings on the patient's nails. Which of the following can be the type of poisoning in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thallium Patient with alopecia, Loss of eyebrow , abnormal (dystrophy ?) nails.and behavioral abnormality point towards diagnosis of Thallium poisoning.

Highyeild:

Thallium - Used in rat poison and ant killer both odorless and Clinical feature: Abdominal pain Alopecia Painful ascending sensory motor neuropathy Maculopapular rash in butterfly pattern Loss of lateral 1/3rd eyebrow Mental status changes and lethargy Triad: Alopecia+skin rash+Peripheral neuropathy Medicolegal importance- accidental intoxication as well as a criminal poison in some cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Arsenic - will show Mees lines on fingernails (transverse white bands),Pigmentation (hypo or hyper) and Hyperkeratosis. Option B. Lead -Chronic lead poisoning causes Plumbism/saturnism. will have circumoral pallor as the earliest manifestation. Blood smear can show punctate basophilia. Option D. Mercury - can lead to a wide array of GI, neurologic , and renal symptoms including loose teeth, salivation, burning sensation in the mouth, tremors, erethism, nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria, neurasthenia, and acrodynia.

questions.text: During a certain trial, the lawyer of the defendant asked a leading question and the opposite lawyer quickly raised an objection. The judge sustained the appeal and requested the defense lawyer to avoid asking such questions. Leading questions can't be allowed in any of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cross Examination Leading questions can only be asked during cross-examination and not during examination-in-chief or re-examination unless and until the court allows.

Highyeild:

Sec. 141 IEA – Defines leading Questions Sec. 142 IEA – It says where leading questions are not allowed in which phase of trial. Sec. 143 IEA – Where leading questions are allowed. Leading questions are allowed in cross examination Exception is the leading question allowed in chief examination when the witness becomes hostile. Legal procedure - Leading Questions can be put by Judge in any part of the trial . In Reexamination, the leading questions are absolutely not allowed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Examination in Chief - Examination in chief is the first examination of witnesses after the oath . It is the state in which a party called a witness to examine him in chief for the purpose of eliciting from the witness all the material facts within his knowledge which tend to prove the party's case. It is also known as Direct Examination. Option B. Direct Examination - The direct examination or examination-in-chief is one stage in the process of adducing evidence from witnesses in a court of law. Direct examination is the questioning of a witness by the lawyer/side/party that called such witness in a trial. Option D. A dying declaration is a statement made by a declarant, who is unavailable to testify in court (typically because of the declarant's death ), who made the statement under a belief of certain or impending death.

questions.text: Identify the wound in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Defence Wounds The image showed a wound on the palmar side of hand , suggesting he/she was trying to grasp the weapon; the wound is also noted along fingers suggesting some double edged weapon is likely the crime weapon.

Highyeild:

Defense wounds- Defense wounds are seen when the victim attempts to ward off a knife either by seizing it or by raising forearms and hands in order to protect other body regions (head, neck, chest). Traditionally a distinction is made in the literature between active and passive defense wounds. According to this distinction active defense wounds occur when the victim grasps the knife with the hand with the injury then being located on the palmar side of the hand. The passive wound type is sustained when the victim raises their hands or arms to protect the attacked body region ; in this case the injuries will primarily be located on the extensor side. If in spite of multiple stabs, no defense injuries are found, it has to be considered that the victim may have been unable to react or impaired in his ability to defend himself already before the use of sharp force: for example in knife attacks on a sleeping person, in unexpected assaults and in victims made unconscious before the attack. The absence of defense wounds is also observed when the victim is held or tied.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Postmortem Cuts - Postmortem injuries are those injuries that definitely occurred after death. Perimortem injuries are those injuries that occurred around the time of death, perhaps a few days or a few hours before death, or a few hours, few days, a few weeks, or even possibly a few months or longer after death. Option B. Antemortem Injury - An injury that occurs before death with evidence of healing (re- formed bone with round, smooth edges) .
